caseTitle: NKAWIE STOOL VERSUS KWADWO AND OTHERS
summary: The case of NKAWIE STOOL v. KWADWO AND OTHERS involved an appeal from a Land Court judgment that non-suited the plaintiff with liberty to bring a fresh action. The defendants appealed this decision to the West African Court of Appeal, but a preliminary objection was raised that the order was interlocutory and thus required special leave to appeal, which had not been obtained. The court held that an order dismissing an action without prejudice to re-filing does not finally determine the rights of the parties and is therefore interlocutory. Relying on Isaacs & Sons v. Salbstein, the court applied the test of whether the judgment finally disposes of the parties' rights, concluding that it does not. As special leave was not obtained, the appeal was struck out.

jurisdiction.court: West African Court of Appeal, Gold Coast Session

citations: Isaacs & Sons v. Salbstein [1916] 2 K.B. 139, C.A.
Samodua and Another v. Konadi and Another (W.A.C.A., March 29, 1954, unreported)
Bozson v. Altrincham Urban Council [1903] 1 K.B. 547, C.A.

rationaleHighlights: An order that non-suits a plaintiff with liberty to bring a fresh action does not finally dispose of the parties' rights.
Such an order is interlocutory, not final.
Special leave to appeal is required for interlocutory orders under the West African Court of Appeal Ordinance.
The appeal was improperly brought without special leave.
The test for finality is whether the judgment conclusively determines the rights of the parties.
Precedent from Isaacs & Sons v. Salbstein was applied.
Samodua case was distinguished due to different procedural posture.
Appeal struck out for lack of jurisdiction.
